words.definition: A step-by-step procedure for solving a problem or accomplishing a task, especially by a computer.
To distribute or assign resources, memory, or tasks for a specific purpose.
The process of reserving a block of memory for data.
To examine something in detail to understand it better or draw conclusions.
A note or comment added to a text or diagram to explain or clarify.
Application Programming Interface; a set of protocols and tools for building software applications.
A software program designed to perform a specific function for the user.
A value passed to a function or program when it is called.
A data structure containing a collection of elements, each identified by an index.
Not occurring at the same time; in computing, operations that occur independently of the main program flow.
The process of verifying the identity of a user or system.
The process of granting or denying access to resources based on permissions.
The server-side part of an application that handles data processing and storage.
The maximum rate of data transfer across a network path.
An institution for receiving, lending, exchanging, and safeguarding money; also, the land beside a body of water.
A number system using only 0 and 1; also, compiled code that can be executed directly by a computer.
A data type with only two possible values: true or false.
A temporary storage area for data being transferred between two locations.
An error or flaw in software that causes incorrect or unexpected behavior.
A form of instruction set designed for efficient execution by a software interpreter.
A hardware or software component that stores data for faster future access.
A function passed as an argument to another function, to be executed later.
A blueprint for creating objects in object-oriented programming, defining properties and methods.
A computer or software that requests services from a server.
Remote servers accessed over the internet for storing, managing, and processing data.
Instructions written in a programming language that a computer can execute.
To convert source code into machine code or bytecode.
A program that translates source code into machine code or bytecode.
A modular, reusable piece of software that performs a specific function.
To reduce the size of data using encoding algorithms.
The ability of a system to handle multiple tasks simultaneously.
Settings that define how software or hardware operates.
A value that cannot be changed during program execution.
A lightweight, standalone package that includes everything needed to run software.
Central Processing Unit; the primary component that executes instructions in a computer.
An organized collection of structured data stored electronically.
To find and fix errors in software.
To convert encrypted data back to its original form.
A preset value or behavior used when no alternative is specified.
A software component that another component relies on to function.
To release and install software for use in a production environment.
A feature or practice that is no longer recommended and may be removed in future versions.
A process that, given a particular input, will always produce the same output.
A person who writes and maintains software code.
A file system structure that contains files and other directories.
Characterized by constant change; in computing, referring to processes that occur during execution.
An individual item in a data structure such as an array or list.
To include one thing within another, such as code within a document.
To convert data into a coded format to prevent unauthorized access.
A URL where an API can be accessed by a client application.
The context in which software runs, including operating system and configuration.
A mistake or problem in software that prevents correct operation.
An action or occurrence detected by a program that may trigger a response.
An error condition that disrupts the normal flow of program execution.
To run or carry out instructions in a program.
A combination of values, variables, and operators that evaluates to a result.
An add-on that extends the functionality of software.
A container for storing data on a computer.
To select items from a collection based on specific criteria.
A security system that monitors and controls network traffic.
A data type representing numbers with decimal points.
A platform providing a foundation for developing software applications.
The client-side part of an application that users interact with directly.
A reusable block of code that performs a specific task.
Automatic memory management that reclaims space used by objects no longer in use.
A distributed version control system for tracking changes in source code.
Accessible from anywhere in a program; having worldwide scope.
Graphics Processing Unit; a processor optimized for rendering graphics and parallel computing.
A fixed-size value generated from input data using a mathematical function.
Metadata at the beginning of a file or network packet.
A region of memory used for dynamic allocation.
A technique designed for solving a problem more quickly when classic methods are too slow.
Hypertext Transfer Protocol; the foundation of data communication on the web.
Integrated Development Environment; software that combines tools for coding, debugging, and testing.
Unable to be changed after creation.
To put a design or plan into effect; to write code that fulfills a specification.
To bring external code or data into a program.
A numerical position in an array or other data structure; a database structure for fast lookups.
To set up initial values and prepare for use.
Data provided to a program or function.
A specific occurrence of an object created from a class.
A whole number without a decimal point.
A shared boundary across which components exchange information; a contract defining methods.
A program that executes instructions directly without prior compilation.
To repeat a process, typically over elements in a collection.
JavaScript Object Notation; a lightweight data interchange format.
A method of executing computer code that involves compilation during execution rather than prior to execution.
The core component of an operating system that manages system resources.
An identifier used to access values in a data structure; a cryptographic secret.
A reserved word in a programming language with special meaning.
The time interval between a cause and its effect in a system.
A collection of pre-written code that can be reused in programs.
A connection between elements; to combine object files into an executable.
An ordered collection of elements.
To transfer data or programs into memory.
Accessible only within a limited scope; stored on the current device.
A record of events or messages generated by software.
The reasoning and decision-making processes in a program.
A programming construct that repeats a block of code.
A branch of AI where systems learn from data to improve performance.
Hardware or storage used to hold data and instructions for processing.
To combine two or more items into one.
Data that describes other data.
A function associated with an object or class.
Software that connects different applications or components.
A self-contained unit of code that can be imported and used.
Able to be changed after creation.
A container that holds identifiers to avoid naming conflicts.
Specific to a particular platform or environment.
A group of interconnected computers and devices.
A point in a network or data structure.
A special value representing the absence of a value.
An instance of a class containing data and methods.
To make as effective or efficient as possible.
The action of making the best or most effective use of a resource.
Data produced by a program or function.
To replace inherited behavior with new implementation.
A bundle of related code or software.
A variable in a function definition that receives arguments.
To analyze and interpret structured data.
The location of a file or directory in a file system.
How well a system executes its functions.
Authorization to access or modify resources.
The smallest unit of a digital image.
The hardware and software environment where applications run.
Software that adds features to an existing application.
A variable that stores the memory address of another value.
A communication endpoint; to adapt software for different platforms.
A running instance of a program.
The live environment where software is used by end users.
The process of creating software using programming languages.
A set of rules governing data communication.
A request for data from a database.
A data structure where elements are processed in order of arrival.
Random Access Memory; volatile memory for temporary data storage.
A technique where a function calls itself.
To restructure code without changing its external behavior.
A value that points to data stored elsewhere.
Regular Expression; a pattern for matching text.
To generate a visual output from data or code.
A storage location for code and version history.
A message sent to a server asking for a response.
Data sent back from a server in reply to a request.
The period when a program is executing; the environment that runs code.
To adjust size or capacity to handle varying loads.
The structure or organization of a database or data format.
The region of code where a variable is accessible.
A program written in a scripting language.
Software Development Kit; tools for building applications for a platform.
A computer or software that provides services to clients.
A period of interaction between a user and a system.
Programs and operating information used by a computer.
The origin of data or the original code of a program.
The process of tailoring code for specific types or values to improve performance.
A data structure with last-in-first-out access; the set of technologies used.
The current condition or values in a system at a point in time.
A single instruction in a programming language.
Fixed at compile time; belonging to a class rather than an instance.
Hardware or services for saving data persistently.
A sequence of characters representing text.
A data type that groups related variables.
The rules governing the structure of statements in a language.
A collection of components working together.
A predefined structure used as a starting point.
A text-based interface for interacting with a computer.
To verify that software works as expected.
A sequence of instructions that can run concurrently with others.
The amount of data or processes handled within a specific period.
A unit of data representing authentication or lexical element.
A method of optimization that uses execution traces to identify hot code paths.
A category for a piece of data that determines what operations can be performed on it.
User Interface; the visual elements users interact with.
To modify data or software to a newer version.
To transfer data from a local system to a remote server.
Uniform Resource Locator; the address of a resource on the internet.
A person who operates or interacts with a system.
A program that performs a specific useful task.
User Experience; the overall experience of using a product.
To check that data meets required standards or formats.
Data stored in a variable or returned by an expression.
A named storage location for data in a program.
A specific release or iteration of software.
Simulated by software rather than existing physically.
An emulation of a computer system providing the functionality of a physical computer.
A type indicating the absence of a value.
The World Wide Web; a system of interlinked hypertext documents.
A small application or component in a user interface.
Extensible Markup Language; a format for structuring data.
To produce a value from a generator function.
